{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127796,"name":"Chris (Mentor|5032)","username":"Thermo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thermo/{size}/175987_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T00:40:11.386Z","cooked":"

Need a little sanity check - working on a telescoping boom design for charged up and I am wondering if we need to worry about the robot tipping.

I’ve been looking and I don’t see any large counterweights being used on other older designs.

How does everyone handling the potential for tipping?

Are there any rough guidelines or calc tools?

Thanks!
Chris

Time simplest thing I can think of is battery positioning. That should be heavy enough to counter any possible tipping

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-17T00:47:47.934Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":430,"readers_count":429,"score":121.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423488,"topic_slug":"telescoping-boom-and-tipping","display_username":"Peter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53708,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Waffles | Team Captain"},"post_url":"/t/telescoping-boom-and-tipping/423488/2","custom_user_title":"Waffles | Team Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127811,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T01:13:34.237Z","cooked":"

Drivetrains last year were more than capable of flipping those robots over - and most were pretty low COG. I would definitely keep it in the back of my mind. Tipping when changing direction, accelerating, or stopping is a much bigger issue than static “reach the arm out” tipping.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-17T01:13:49.679Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":393,"readers_count":392,"score":88.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423488,"topic_slug":"telescoping-boom-and-tipping","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/telescoping-boom-and-tipping/423488/3","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127829,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T01:46:05.323Z","cooked":"

Thanks to Ron and James from 4152 we reviewed different drive train sizes and their potential for tipping with a 4’ arm.
Here’s the rough notes from their work. Battery position is the easiest way to reduce the chance of tipping.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zn425GRv9Zs0pULKvH-fu38prRJVYRvy/view?usp=sharing

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-17T01:46:05.323Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":331,"readers_count":330,"score":66.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423488,"topic_slug":"telescoping-boom-and-tipping","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zn425GRv9Zs0pULKvH-fu38prRJVYRvy/view?usp=sharing","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":41}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/telescoping-boom-and-tipping/423488/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127856,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-17T02:25:16.201Z","cooked":"

I would also note that an arm with enough power in a degree of freedom that will take it through the ground may be able to reverse the tipping.

I call 330 as my witness. (2005 L.A. Regional at least once, 2016 L.A. Regional and Einstein).

Do you need to worry about tipping, yes–at least going towards “what happens next”. Should you design to prevent it, or reverse it when it happens? Well, if an accident happens…

Awesome - thanks for the input - I had a couple ideas on how to cut down on the weight and mitigate the problem if we run into it.

Chris

You can also programmatically reduce the acceleration with a slewrate limiter. Good fall back.
